publications.title: Selective Sensing of Nerve Agent Simulant via Dirhodium(II,II) Paddlewheel Complexes Featuring Pendant Hemilabile Thioether Ligands
Chromogenic detection of the organophosphate nerve agent simulant DCP mediated by rhodium(II,II)paddlewheel complexes.

aboutLong:
Ernest Bennin is a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. He holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Chemistry from the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST), Ghana. He is a member of the NSF Center for Computer-Assisted Synthesis (NSF-CCAS), the American Chemical Society (ACS), and NOBCChE. His current research focuses on:

Novel ligand designs (organic synthesis) | Rhodium paddlewheel complexes synthesis | Utilization of rhodium paddlewheel complexes in asymmetric catalysis | Development of Rh(II)-based chemical sensors for chromogenic detection of biomolecules
aboutShort: Ernest Bernin is a doctoral candidate in chemistry at the University of Tennessee-Knoxville, exploring research at the intersection of ligand design, synthesis, asymmetric catalysis, and chemical probes for poisonous substance detection.
